instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Hello everyone, [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]I'm working on a liquid damage macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. It got 3 pads (Pin2 NC, Pin3/4 <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>) missing on the lcd connector. I already [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]ran a wire from pin 3&4 of the LVDS connector to pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR> but i still don't have a backlight. My output voltage at <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 8.42v. According to Louis sticky post this might be related to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> not boosting the backlight. I proceeded with troubleshooting this area since the problem is most likely on this circuitry. My readings on <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> are the following: <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 1.46v, <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> 1.38v, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.09v, <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> 8.55v, <SIGNAL>PPHVS0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 8.40v. Should my voltages on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> be higher? Do you think my <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is no good?

Thanks![/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Don't know where to start here, did you read the sticky on backlight repair?
WHY IS THERE A 2010 LCD CONNECTOR ON THAT BOARD????!!! WTF!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: I never said i didn't know were to start LOOL I just wanted some clarification so I understand. To answer your question yes I read the sticky note. I just had a few questions.  I didn't know the 2010 model connector wasn't compatible with this model. I thought they were all the same. Maybe thats my issue. I guess Im better off answerign my own questions. Thanks for the answer lool

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
The LCD cable doesn't even properly fit in such a connector, how? They don't even look the same.
1 Connector is wrong
2 <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is too low
3 <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is probably fucked

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> has never been lower than 2.7v for me. If you ever want to know what you should expect at a voltage divider, use this calculator. [url]http://www.raltron.com/cust/tools/voltage_divider.asp[/url] If you put 8.4v as starting voltage, 300000 for R1, and 100000 for R2, it will show you 2.8v is what to expect. See <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> in the schematic? This is a voltage divider.

There is a chance the feedback via is broken between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and ball A5 of <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>(<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>). Check under <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> for what ball A5 for feedback looks like.

Check the sticky for more info and let us know what you find.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Thanks for the info Louis!! I will install the correct connector and take it from there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 5888"]<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> has never been lower than 2.7v for me. If you ever want to know what you should expect at a voltage divider, use this calculator. [url]http://www.raltron.com/cust/tools/voltage_divider.asp[/url] If you put 8.4v as starting voltage, 300000 for R1, and 100000 for R2, it will show you 2.8v is what to expect. See <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> in the schematic? This is a voltage divider.

There is a chance the feedback via is broken between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and ball A5 of <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>(<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>). Check under <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> for what ball A5 for feedback looks like.

Check the sticky for more info and let us know what you find.[/QUOTE]

Im happy to say that I was able to fix this macbook air with no backlight. I had to reinstall the correct LVDS connector and make a jumper from the bottom of the board to the top to fix the blown trace. This was a awesome repair. It taught me a lot of things. Thanks for all the help!!
